events.description: Wilhelm Röntgen discovered X-rays (November 8, 1895) while experimenting with cathode rays in Würzburg. Noticed fluorescent screen glowing across room. First X-ray photograph: his wife's hand showing bones (December 22). Published 'On a New Kind of Rays' December 28.

protocolEffects.Inference: Revealed invisible penetrating radiation—demonstrated phenomena existed beyond visible spectrum, opening investigation of atomic-scale processes through their effects.

events.title: Radioactivity Priority Disputes
events.description: Multiple competing claims to radioactivity discovery. Becquerel fails to credit Niepce de Saint-Victor's 1857 work. Thompson loses priority by delaying publication. Marie Curie nearly excluded from 1903 Nobel.

events.title: J.J. Thomson Discovers the Electron
events.description: J.J. Thomson's cathode ray experiments at Cambridge (April 1897) measured charge-to-mass ratio showing particles ~1000x lighter than hydrogen atom. Concluded rays were streams of subatomic particles—electrons. Published in Philosophical Magazine August 1897.

protocolEffects.Inference: Proved atoms were divisible—existence of subatomic particles opened investigation of atomic structure, launching modern physics.
protocolEffects.Quality: Quantitative measurements enabled verification—charge/mass ratio could be independently measured, confirming electron's existence and properties across laboratories.

events.title: Curies Discover Radium and Polonium
events.description: Marie and Pierre Curie isolated radioactive elements from uranium ore through systematic fractional crystallization. Discovered polonium (July 1898) and radium (December 1898). Required processing tons of pitchblende. Established quantitative radiation measurement methods.

protocolEffects.Inference: Systematic chemical separation isolated radioactive elements—demonstrated new substances could be discovered through their radiation signatures, creating new detection method.
protocolEffects.Quality: Quantitative radioactivity measurements enabled verification—radiation levels could be measured and compared, making radioactive element discoveries testable across laboratories.

events.title: American Physical Society Founded
events.description: American Physical Society founded May 20, 1899 at Columbia University with 36 charter members. Created professional organization for physicists with PhD as implicit membership requirement. Published Physical Review from 1913.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Professional society formalized physics credentials—membership and officer positions became markers of status, creating organized physics community with gatekeeping.
protocolEffects.Quality: PhD requirement established baseline—society members had formal research training, ensuring professional standards and excluding amateur practitioners.

events.title: Planck Introduces Quantum Theory
events.description: Max Planck presented blackbody radiation solution to German Physical Society (December 14, 1900). proposes energy radiated in discrete quanta (E=hν) to match Wien's and Rayleigh's experimental data. introduces Planck's constant h.

protocolEffects.Inference: Quantization revolutionized physics—discrete energy packets resolved blackbody spectrum problem classical physics couldn't explain, demonstrating fundamental physics needed radical revision not incremental refinement.

events.title: GE Research Laboratory Founded
events.description: General Electric established first industrial research laboratory in Schenectady, NY (December 1900). Willis Whitney as director hired PhD scientists for systematic research. Model for corporate R&D—combine basic research with commercial application.

protocolEffects.Inference: Institutionalized industrial research—corporations created dedicated laboratories for systematic investigation, applying academic research methods to commercial problems.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Created non-academic research careers—PhDs could work in industry laboratories with research freedom and better pay than universities, diversifying career paths.

events.title: Library of Congress Classification
events.description: Library of Congress develops LC Classification system as alternative to Dewey Decimal. Divided knowledge by subject (A-Z) then subdivided. Greater specificity for research materials. adopts by most academic/research libraries.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Detailed classification enabled precise organization—research libraries could catalog specialized scientific works more granularly than Dewey's broader categories, improving retrieval of technical literature.

events.title: First Nobel Prizes Awarded
events.description: Inaugural Nobel Prizes awarded December 10, 1901 in Stockholm. Physics: Röntgen (X-rays), Chemistry: van 't Hoff (chemical thermodynamics), Medicine: von Behring (serum therapy). Established from Alfred Nobel's will, $265M endowment (today's dollars).

protocolEffects.Coordination: International prestige award resolved priority disputes—Nobel Committee's decisions established authoritative recognition, reducing bitter conflicts over discovery credit that plagued earlier science.

events.title: N-rays Scandal
events.description: French physicist Blondlot 'discovers' N-rays, 120 scientists confirm in 300 papers, French Academy awards prize. Robert Wood exposes as self-deception—prism removed, Blondlot still 'saw' patterns. Pathological science.

events.title: Einstein's Annus Mirabilis
events.description: Albert Einstein publishes four revolutionary papers in Annalen der Physik while working at Swiss patent office: photoelectric effect (March), Brownian motion (May), special relativity (June), mass-energy equivalence E=mc² (September). transforms physics from clerk's desk.

protocolEffects.Inference: Thought experiments generated revolutionary theories—pure reasoning about light, motion, and relativity produced testable predictions without laboratory apparatus, validating theoretical physics as discovery method.
protocolEffects.Quality: Multiple testable predictions enabled verification—photoelectric effect, mass-energy conversion, and relativity effects gave experimentalists specific phenomena to measure, making radical theories falsifiable.

events.title: Chemical Abstracts Service Founded
events.description: American Chemical Society launches Chemical Abstracts (January 1, 1907) to index and abstract all worldwide chemical publications. William Noyes as founding editor. Abstracted 12,000 papers first year, over 500,000 annually by 1960s.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Comprehensive abstracting made research discoverable—chemists could scan abstracts to find relevant work across thousands of journals without reading every publication.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Systematic indexing prevented literature from being lost—organized by subject and formula, making chemical knowledge retrievable as publications exploded beyond individual tracking capability.

events.title: Geiger Counter Invented
events.description: Hans Geiger develops the Geiger counter while working with Ernest Rutherford at University of Manchester. Electrical detector registered individual alpha particles through gas ionization, producing audible clicks. First instrument to detect and count single subatomic particles.

protocolEffects.Inference: Made invisible radiation measurable and quantifiable—transformed radioactivity from qualitative observation (fogged photographic plates) to precise counting of particle emissions, enabling systematic nuclear physics experiments.

events.title: Wilson Cloud Chamber
events.description: C.T.R. Wilson invents cloud chamber—supersaturated vapor condensed on ionized gas molecules, making charged particle tracks visible as trails. First photographs of particle tracks 1911. enables study of cosmic rays and radioactive decay.

protocolEffects.Inference: Made subatomic particle paths visible—transformed particles from abstract theoretical entities to observable tracks researchers could photograph, measure, and analyze directly.

events.title: Piltdown Man Hoax
events.description: Charles Dawson presents fake 'missing link' fossil—human skull with orangutan jaw. Broadly accepted for 41 years until exposed in 1953. Most significant fraud in anthropology, impeded African hominin research.

events.title: Rockefeller Foundation Chartered
events.description: John D. Rockefeller endows foundation with $4B (today's dollars). Pioneers 'scientific philanthropy'—systematic, professional research funding at scale. Invests $100M in health programs by 1950, establishing model for strategic foundation funding.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Created professional philanthropic funding—systematic grant programs with expert evaluation replaced arbitrary patronage, distributing resources based on research merit and strategic priorities.
protocolEffects.Quality: Foundation staff evaluated proposals systematically—established professional program officers and advisory boards for funding decisions, ensuring quality standards in philanthropic science support.

events.title: American Association of University Professors Founded
events.description: AAUP establishes academic freedom principles and tenure system standards, creating job security and professional autonomy for researchers.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Tenure system provided career stability—researchers could pursue controversial or long-term work without fear of dismissal, protecting intellectual independence.
protocolEffects.Quality: Academic freedom protected research integrity—faculty could challenge prevailing theories and publish unpopular findings without institutional censorship.

events.title: National Research Council Established
events.description: National Academy of Sciences creates National Research Council during WWI to coordinate American research. Develops formalized peer review procedures in 1920s-1930s to ensure fairness beyond established elite. First systematic external refereeing of grant proposals.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Centralized national research coordination—NRC unified scattered efforts into organized national science policy and funding recommendations.
protocolEffects.Quality: Formalized peer review created systematic evaluation—external referees judged proposals and publications by methodological standards rather than personal connections or reputation.

events.title: Interlibrary Loan Standards
events.description: American Library Association formalizes interlibrary loan protocols, enabling researchers to access materials across institutional boundaries through standardized borrowing procedures.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Cross-institutional access broke library silos—researchers could request materials from any participating library, making collections nationwide accessible from single institution.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Distributed access reduced pressure on individual collections—rare materials could be borrowed rather than purchased, enabling smaller libraries to provide access to broader literature.

events.title: International Research Council Founded
events.description: Post-WWI organization creates framework to coordinate international scientific collaboration. Initially excludes Central Powers (Germany, Austria) but establishes global coordination structure.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Created permanent international coordination body—replaced ad-hoc collaborations with standing organization for managing global scientific cooperation.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Disciplinary unions (chemistry, physics, astronomy) enabled field-specific international communication—specialists could coordinate globally within domains.

events.title: Eddington Eclipse Expedition Verifies General Relativity
events.description: Two British expeditions (Príncipe & Sobral, Brazil) led by Eddington, Dyson, and Davidson measure starlight deflection during May 29 total eclipse. November 6 announcement verifies Einstein's theory. Headlines 'Revolution in Science' make Einstein world-famous.

protocolEffects.Quality: Dramatic experimental verification validated radical theory—observational test of general relativity during eclipse provided crucial empirical confirmation of mathematical prediction.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Massive public attention brought theoretical physics into mainstream—newspaper coverage made Einstein celebrity, demonstrating science could capture public imagination.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Post-WWI British scientists verified German theory—demonstrated science transcended national conflicts, international collaboration could resume after war.

events.title: Physical Review Requires Referee Reports
events.description: Physical Review formalizes mandatory pre-publication peer review by expert referees, establishing the modern peer review system.

protocolEffects.Quality: Anonymous referee reports created systematic quality filter—experts evaluated methodology before publication, catching errors and ensuring rigor.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Rejection power shifted to referees—editors relied on peer evaluation rather than personal judgment, distributing quality control across research community.

events.title: Bell Telephone Laboratories Founded
events.description: AT&T establishes Bell Labs in New York, creating one of the most influential industrial research laboratories. Will produce transistors (1947), lasers (1958), Unix (1969), and foundational computing technologies.

protocolEffects.Inference: Corporate basic research laboratory normalized long-term investigation—Bell Labs combined fundamental physics with engineering applications, creating hybrid research model.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Stable industrial positions attracted top PhDs—offered research freedom with better resources than universities, making corporate labs competitive with academia for talent.

events.title: Fisher's Statistical Methods for Research Workers
events.description: Ronald Fisher publishes Statistical Methods for Research Workers based on Rothamsted agricultural work. Introduces ANOVA, randomization, and experimental design principles. Transforms agricultural experimentation, remains in print 50+ years.

protocolEffects.Inference: Statistical methods enabled rigorous experimental design—randomization and analysis of variance let researchers extract signals from noisy biological data, making agriculture scientifically analyzable.
protocolEffects.Quality: Significance testing provided objective evaluation standard—p-values and confidence intervals gave researchers systematic way to assess whether results were real or chance fluctuations.

events.title: Kammerer Midwife Toad Affair
events.description: Austrian biologist Paul Kammerer accused of injecting India ink into toad specimens to fake Lamarckian inheritance. Nature publishes accusation. Kammerer commits suicide 6 weeks later. Modern evidence suggests he was framed.

events.title: Electron Microscope Invented
events.description: Ernst Ruska and Max Knoll develop electron microscope at Technical University of Berlin. Uses electron beams instead of light, achieves 400x magnification initially, later reaches atomic resolution. Ruska wins Nobel Prize 1986.

protocolEffects.Inference: Revealed structures at atomic scale—electron wavelength much shorter than light enabled visualization of molecules, viruses, and atomic lattices impossible with optical microscopes.

events.title: International Council of Scientific Unions Founded
events.description: ICSU replaces International Research Council, creating permanent international coordination structure. Establishes disciplinary unions (IUPAC for chemistry, IUPAP for physics, etc.) for field-specific global coordination.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Disciplinary unions enabled field-specific global governance—each domain could set international standards, coordinate projects, and resolve disputes within specialty.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Permanent structure facilitated ongoing collaboration—standing committees and regular meetings replaced episodic coordination, making international cooperation continuous.

events.title: Lawrence's Cyclotron
events.description: Ernest Lawrence invents cyclotron particle accelerator at UC Berkeley. Uses magnetic field to spiral particles in circular path, accelerating them to high energies. First model: 4.5 inches diameter. Later versions enable nuclear physics experiments.

protocolEffects.Inference: High-energy particle collisions revealed atomic structure—accelerated particles could probe nuclear forces and create new isotopes, opening experimental investigation of subatomic realm.

events.title: Fisher's Design of Experiments
events.description: Ronald Fisher publishes The Design of Experiments formalizing experimental design methodology. Introduces null hypothesis testing, factorial designs, and Latin squares. Creates systematic framework for planning experiments and interpreting results.

protocolEffects.Inference: Systematic experimental design maximized information extraction—factorial experiments tested multiple factors simultaneously, making research more efficient than one-variable-at-a-time approaches.
protocolEffects.Quality: Null hypothesis testing provided decision framework—researchers could systematically determine if effects were real or chance, standardizing interpretation of experimental results.

events.title: Xerography Invented
events.description: Chester Carlson and Otto Kornei create first xerographic copy on October 22 ('10.-22.-38 ASTORIA'). Electrostatic copying process—faster and cheaper than manual copying or photography. Commercialized by Xerox 1959.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Rapid cheap copying enabled personal archives—researchers could copy and keep documents rather than relying on library access, building portable reference collections.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Easy distribution accelerated sharing—copied papers could be mailed to colleagues worldwide, making literature distribution faster and more widespread than print journals alone.

events.title: Lysenkoism Suppression of Genetics
events.description: Stalin-backed Lysenko declares genetics 'bourgeois pseudoscience.' Geneticist Vavilov arrested, dies in prison 1943. 3,000+ biologists dismissed or imprisoned, many executed. USSR genetics banned until 1964.

events.title: Office of Scientific Research and Development Created
events.description: Executive Order 8807 establishes OSRD on June 28 under Vannevar Bush. Coordinates almost all wartime military R&D—850 employees, 2,500 contracts, $536M. Produces radar, penicillin mass production, proximity fuse, manages Manhattan Project.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Demonstrated federal government could coordinate massive scientific mobilization—centralized direction of thousands of researchers across universities and industry proved large-scale research organization was possible.

events.title: Manhattan Project Begins
events.description: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers begins Manhattan Project—secret program coordinating 130,000 people across 30 sites (Los Alamos, Oak Ridge, Hanford). $2B budget (1945 dollars). Produces first atomic weapons by July 1945.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Unprecedented scale of organized research—demonstrated thousands of scientists could work on coordinated problem across multiple institutions with centralized management and security.
protocolEffects.Inference: Big science model emerged—complex problems required teams, specialized facilities, and massive resources beyond individual researchers or single universities.

events.title: Vannevar Bush Report
events.description: Vannevar Bush publishes 'Science: The Endless Frontier' (July 1945) proposing National Research Foundation (later NSF). Argues government should fund basic research, researchers should direct agendas. Blueprint for postwar American science policy.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Established framework for federal science funding—government would support research systematically through grants rather than episodic contracts, creating stable funding infrastructure.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Called for national knowledge infrastructure—proposed centralized systems for preserving and disseminating scientific information, laying groundwork for federal databases and archives.

events.title: ENIAC Completes First Calculation
events.description: First programmable electronic computer (Mauchly & Eckert) performs thermonuclear weapon calculations for Los Alamos on December 10. Millions of discrete calculations previously impossible by hand. Publicly unveiled February 1946.

protocolEffects.Inference: Electronic computation enabled previously impossible calculations—complex numerical problems requiring millions of operations became solvable, opening computational approach to physics, engineering, and mathematics.

events.title: Atomic Energy Commission Created
events.description: Atomic Energy Act creates AEC (August 1, 1946) with civilian control over nuclear research and weapons. Massive peacetime research budget, national laboratories (Los Alamos, Oak Ridge, Argonne). First centralized federal science agency.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Federal agency centralized nuclear research—government directly managed research agenda, facilities, and funding rather than coordinating through universities.
protocolEffects.Inference: National laboratory system created big science infrastructure—specialized facilities (reactors, particle accelerators) enabled research impossible at universities.

events.title: Transistor Invented at Bell Labs
events.description: John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley invent transistor at Bell Labs (December 23, 1947, announced June 1948). Solid-state amplifier replaces vacuum tubes. Launches electronics revolution, enables modern computing.

protocolEffects.Inference: Miniaturized electronics enabled new instrumentation—transistors made portable, reliable scientific instruments possible, expanding experimental capabilities beyond laboratory-bound vacuum tube equipment.

events.title: National Science Foundation
events.description: National Science Foundation Act signed May 10, 1950. Creates independent federal agency to fund basic research across all sciences. First director appointed 1951, first grants 1952. Implements peer review grant system and merit-based allocation.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Systematic federal funding across disciplines—NSF distributed research support through competitive merit review rather than political allocation, creating organized national research investment.

startsEra.name: Institutional Science
startsEra.substrate: PDF and web publishing; email and HTTP/HTTPS; DOIs and ORCIDs for persistent identification; XML metadata schemas (Dublin Core, JATS); citation databases (Web of Science, Scopus, Google Scholar); preprint servers (arXiv, bioRxiv); institutional authentication (Shibboleth); publisher platforms; data repositories (Zenodo, Figshare); version control (Git); federal grant systems (NSF, NIH); bibliometric indices (Impact Factor, h-index); formalized peer review infrastructure; cloud computing
startsEra.overview: Federal funding transforms science at scale. The creation of NSF (1950) and expansion of NIH establish stable, large-scale public funding—replacing the fragmented systems of previous eras. The five protocols, which first emerged together in Organized Science and professionalized over the following century, now become integrated into a self-reinforcing global system: federal grants fund research → peer review validates claims → journals disseminate findings → citations allocate credit → tenure rewards productivity. This configuration achieves immense success and global dominance—but it was never intentionally designed. It emerged organically. Now it faces mounting stress from challenges it wasn't built to handle.

howProtocolsFunctioned.Inference: Federal grants fund hypothesis-driven university research; computers enable new methods
howProtocolsFunctioned.Quality: Anonymous peer review by 2-3 experts determines publication; journal prestige becomes dominant metric
howProtocolsFunctioned.Engagement: Academic journals disseminate findings; conference circuits; email communication
howProtocolsFunctioned.Coordination: Grant cycles + tenure system + citation-based credit align incentives toward prestigious publications

startsEra.success: Unprecedented scale and productivity; moon landing, human genome, internet, quantum computing
startsEra.failure: Reproducibility crisis; funding scarcity; fraud surge; publication monopoly; mental health crisis; platform dependencies

events.title: Scientific Computing Emerges
events.description: UNIVAC I and other early commercial computers become available to research institutions. Enable statistical analysis, numerical modeling, and data processing at scales impossible by hand. Mark beginning of computational science era.

protocolEffects.Inference: Computational analysis enabled new discovery methods—numerical simulations and statistical modeling complemented experimental observation, making complex systems analyzable through calculation.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Digital data storage introduced machine-readable records—research data could be stored on magnetic tape and reanalyzed computationally, though formats were proprietary and fragile.

events.title: Watson & Crick DNA Double Helix Structure
events.description: Watson and Crick publish 842-word paper in Nature on April 25 describing DNA's double helix structure. Build on Franklin's X-ray crystallography data. Famous understatement: 'It has not escaped our notice' genetic copying mechanism. Sparks molecular biology revolution. Watson, Crick, and Wilkins receive 1962 Nobel Prize.

protocolEffects.Inference: Structural model explained heredity mechanism—double helix immediately suggested how DNA could copy itself (complementary base pairing), unifying molecular structure with biological function.
protocolEffects.Quality: X-ray diffraction data provided objective verification—crystallography patterns constrained possible structures, making model testable against physical evidence from Franklin and Wilkins.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Brief elegant paper sparked global research program—molecular biology emerged as discipline within years as researchers worldwide pursued implications of DNA structure.

events.title: NIH Expansion
events.description: NIH budget grew from $2.8M (1945) to $81M (1953) under Director James Shannon, funding multi-institutional clinical trials networks and research centers. Peer review study sections establishes systematic grant evaluation.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Competitive grant system with standardized peer review replaced patronage—merit-based funding allocation across institutions created first systematic national research coordination.
protocolEffects.Quality: Multi-site clinical trials required shared protocols and cross-validation between labs—standardized procedures and mandatory replication became funding requirements.

events.title: CERN Founded
events.description: Twelve European nations establish CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research) in Geneva. First international big science laboratory. Shares costs and expertise for particle physics research too expensive for single nations.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Multinational funding pooled resources—rival European nations cooperated on shared research infrastructure, demonstrating international collaboration could sustain major facilities.
protocolEffects.Inference: Shared particle accelerators democratized access—physicists from member nations could use facilities no single country could afford, making frontier physics accessible beyond superpowers.

events.title: FORTRAN Programming Language Released
events.description: IBM releases FORTRAN (FORmula TRANslation) in April—first high-level programming language. John Backus's team enables scientists to write calculations in mathematical notation rather than machine code. Transforms scientific computing efficiency, becomes standard for numerical computation.

protocolEffects.Inference: High-level programming made computation accessible—scientists could write programs directly without mastering machine code, democratizing computational methods beyond programming specialists.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Standardized language preserved computational methods—FORTRAN programs could be shared and rerun across institutions, making computational procedures reproducible rather than locked in individual machines.

events.title: Sputnik Launch
events.description: Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1 satellite (October 4, 1957). First artificial satellite orbits Earth, transmits radio beeps. Triggers 'Sputnik crisis' in US, catalyzes massive science funding increases and education reforms.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Competition sparked unprecedented funding—US federal science budget exploded in response, NDEA passed 1958, NASA created, demonstrating geopolitics could drive research investment.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Public crisis elevated science priority—Sputnik made scientific competitiveness national security issue, bringing research funding into mainstream political discourse.

events.title: NASA Founded
events.description: National Aeronautics and Space Act creates NASA (July 29, 1958). Consolidates scattered space programs into single civilian agency. Massive budget for space exploration, research, and technology development.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Centralized space research coordination—unified agency managed distributed contractors, research centers, and universities working toward common goals (Moon landing, satellites, probes).
protocolEffects.Inference: Space-based observation platforms enabled global science—satellites provided Earth observation, astronomy, and experimental platforms impossible from ground, opening new research domains.

events.title: First Laser Demonstrated
events.description: Theodore Maiman demonstrates first working laser at Hughes Research Lab on May 16—ruby laser emitting coherent 694nm light. Nature calls it 'probably more important per word than any papers published by Nature over the past century.' Revolutionizes spectroscopy, materials science, and precision measurement.

protocolEffects.Inference: Coherent light enabled unprecedented precision—lasers provided monochromatic, focused beams for spectroscopy, interferometry, and measurement impossible with conventional light sources.

events.title: Telstar Satellite Launches
events.description: AT&T and NASA launch Telstar 1 (July 10, 1962)—first active communications satellite relays live TV, telephone, and data across Atlantic. Enables real-time transatlantic broadcasts and data transmission.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Live satellite communication connected continents—researchers could participate in real-time conferences and data exchanges across oceans, accelerating international collaboration pace.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Instant global communication enabled synchronized projects—international teams could coordinate activities in real-time rather than through delayed correspondence.

events.title: ARPANET Planning Begins
events.description: ARPA initiates development of packet-switching network to connect research computers. J.C.R. Licklider's vision of 'Intergalactic Computer Network' begins taking shape. Lays groundwork for Internet.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Network planning envisioned resource sharing—researchers at different institutions could access remote computers and databases, breaking institutional barriers to computational resources.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Distributed network design enabled decentralized collaboration—no central control point meant network could grow organically as more institutions connected.

events.title: BASIC Programming Language & Dartmouth Time-Sharing
events.description: Kemeny and Kurtz launch BASIC and Dartmouth Time-Sharing System at 4am on May 1. First programming language designed for ease-of-use. Multiple users can edit and run programs simultaneously on remote terminals. Democratizes computing access beyond specialists.

protocolEffects.Inference: Simple programming language made computation accessible—researchers without programming training could write analysis scripts, expanding who could use computational methods.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Time-sharing enabled shared computational resources—multiple researchers could use same computer simultaneously through terminals, maximizing expensive hardware utilization.

events.title: MEDLARS Computerized Medical Database
events.description: National Library of Medicine launches MEDLARS (Medical Literature Analysis and Retrieval System)—first large-scale computerized bibliographic retrieval. Costs $3M, runs on Honeywell 800. Regional centers established. Automates Index Medicus compilation. Foundation for MEDLINE and PubMed.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Computer search replaced manual literature review—physicians and researchers could query database for relevant papers, finding citations in minutes rather than hours of manual searching.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Centralized digital database made medical literature systematically searchable—all indexed papers became discoverable through keyword queries rather than browsing physical volumes.

events.title: Science Citation Index
events.description: Eugene Garfield's Institute for Scientific Information launches SCI, systematically tracking citations. Creates impact factor metric—journal prestige quantified by average citations per article. Transforms evaluation landscape.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Citation indexing made literature discoverable forward in time—researchers could find papers citing earlier work, tracking how ideas evolved and who built on findings.
protocolEffects.Quality: Impact factors quantified influence—journal and researcher prestige became measurable, creating metrics-based evaluation that would dominate hiring and funding decisions.

events.title: ARPANET First Connection
events.description: First host-to-host connection between UCLA and Stanford Research Institute on October 29. System crashed after transmitting 'LO' from 'LOGIN'. By December 5, four-node network operational (UCLA, SRI, UCSB, Utah). First packet-switching network creates infrastructure for distributed research collaboration.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Real-time data exchange between remote computers replaced mailing tapes—researchers could access distant datasets and share results instantly rather than waiting days for physical delivery.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Network enabled resource sharing across institutions—expensive computers became accessible to researchers at connected universities, democratizing computational infrastructure.

events.title: Polywater Delusion
events.description: USSR claims new form of water. Western scientists 'replicate,' Cold War fears escalate, Pentagon funds research. 1973 debunking reveals contamination. Pathological science, not fraud.

events.title: Reverse Transcriptase Discovery
events.description: Temin & Mizutani and Baltimore simultaneously publish in Nature on June 27 discovery of enzyme transcribing RNA to DNA. Challenges central dogma of molecular biology—called 'most dramatic scientific moment of second half of 20th century.' Enables retroviral research and biotechnology tools. 1975 Nobel Prize.

protocolEffects.Inference: Reversed information flow challenged central dogma—RNA-to-DNA transcription revealed molecular biology was more complex than assumed, demonstrating willingness to revise fundamental principles based on evidence.
protocolEffects.Quality: Simultaneous independent discovery validated findings—two labs using different approaches reached same conclusion, providing mutual verification of revolutionary claim.

events.title: Ray Tomlinson Sends First Network Email
events.description: Ray Tomlinson sends first email over ARPANET using @ symbol to specify recipient@host. Creates digital person-to-person messaging for researchers. Becomes primary communication method within years.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Asynchronous messaging accelerated communication—researchers could send detailed technical messages instantly without telephone coordination or postal delays.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Email enabled rapid distributed coordination—teams could discuss, debate, and make decisions through threaded conversations without requiring simultaneous availability.

events.title: Landsat 1 Satellite Launched
events.description: Earth Resources Technology Satellite launches July 23 with Multispectral Scanner (60-meter resolution, four spectral bands). Transmits 100,000+ images by 1974, covering 75% of Earth's surface. First satellite explicitly designed for Earth observation.

protocolEffects.Inference: Systematic global observation from orbit revealed Earth-scale patterns—deforestation, urban growth, geological features became measurable through consistent satellite monitoring impossible from ground.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Continuous archival imaging created temporal record—decades of satellite data preserved Earth's changing surface, enabling historical comparison and trend analysis.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Open data policy made imagery publicly available—researchers worldwide could access same satellite data, democratizing remote sensing beyond institutions with aircraft.

events.title: TCP/IP Protocol Developed
events.description: Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn develop TCP/IP protocols enabling different computer networks to interconnect. 'Inter-networking' design allows heterogeneous networks to exchange data using common protocol.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Universal protocol enabled network interoperability—different institutional networks could connect and communicate, breaking technical barriers to information exchange.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Decentralized design allowed organic growth—networks could join internet without central permission, enabling distributed expansion of research connectivity.

events.title: Summerlin Painted Mice Fraud
events.description: Sloan Kettering researcher William Summerlin uses marker to fake skin graft success. Lab assistant wipes 'transplant' off with alcohol. 'Painting the mice' becomes synonym for research fraud.

events.title: Apple II Personal Computer Released
events.description: Apple releases Apple II (June 1977)—first mass-market personal computer with color graphics, expansion slots, and floppy disk drive. Brings computing power directly to individual researchers' desks at affordable price.

protocolEffects.Inference: Personal computing democratized computational analysis—individual researchers could run programs and analyze data without competing for shared mainframe time, making computation routine rather than special.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Floppy disks enabled portable data storage—researchers could save datasets and transfer them between machines, though fragile magnetic media had limited longevity.

events.title: Sanger Chain-Termination DNA Sequencing
events.description: Frederick Sanger publishes dideoxy chain-termination method in December—dramatically faster and more accurate than his 1975 plus-minus method. Uses dideoxynucleotides as chain terminators. Sequences first complete DNA genome (bacteriophage φX174). Becomes gold standard for genomics. Sanger's second Nobel Prize (1980).

protocolEffects.Inference: Practical DNA sequencing made genetics experimental—researchers could read genetic code directly, transforming molecular biology from structural inference to sequence-based investigation.
protocolEffects.Quality: Reproducible chemistry enabled independent verification—multiple labs could sequence same DNA and compare results, making genetic findings testable across institutions.

events.title: TeX Typesetting System
events.description: Donald Knuth creates TeX after receiving poor-quality galleys in 1977. Releases it in 1978 during sabbatical, typesets his 700-page 'Art of Computer Programming.' Gives researchers direct control over high-quality mathematical typesetting. Open source, still widely used. Foundation for LaTeX (1985).

protocolEffects.Preservation: Author-controlled typesetting preserved mathematical precision—researchers could ensure equations appeared exactly as intended rather than relying on typesetters who might introduce errors.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Free software democratized professional publishing—any researcher could produce publication-quality documents without expensive commercial typesetting services.

events.title: VisiCalc Spreadsheet Launched
events.description: Dan Bricklin and Bob Frankston release VisiCalc for Apple II—first electronic spreadsheet. Users can manipulate data in grid, formulas recalculate automatically. Transforms computational analysis on personal computers.

protocolEffects.Inference: Interactive calculation enabled exploratory analysis—researchers could instantly see how changing parameters affected results, making 'what-if' scenarios practical for data exploration.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Spreadsheet files preserved calculations with data—formulas stored alongside results meant others could verify calculations and rerun analysis with different inputs.

events.title: Bayh-Dole Act
events.description: Federal law enables universities to patent and commercialize federally-funded research. Before 1980, government holds 30,000 patents with <5% licensed. Since then: $1.3T economic growth, 4.2M jobs, 11,000+ startups. Transforms university-industry technology transfer.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Patent incentives aligned academic and commercial goals—universities could profit from discoveries, creating motivation to translate research into practical applications.
protocolEffects.Inference: Commercial potential influenced research agendas—application-oriented work became more fundable and prestigious, shifting some research toward practical problems.

events.title: IBM PC Launched
events.description: IBM releases IBM Personal Computer (August 12, 1981) with open architecture and MS-DOS. Standardizes PC platform, makes business and scientific computing accessible beyond mainframe specialists. Spawns clone market.

protocolEffects.Inference: Standardized platform enabled software ecosystem—scientific programs could run across institutions using same PC architecture, making computational tools portable.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Floppy and hard disk storage made data portable—researchers could archive datasets locally and share via diskettes, though proprietary formats created long-term compatibility issues.

events.title: Darsee Cardiology Fraud
events.description: Harvard researchers catch John Darsee fabricating data in real-time. Investigation reveals fraud spanning Notre Dame, Emory, and Harvard. 82 papers retracted. NIH bars him for 10 years, medical license revoked.

events.title: SMTP Protocol Standardized
events.description: Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (RFC 821) standardizes email transmission. Defines how mail servers exchange messages. Enables universal email exchange across different networks and systems.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Standard email protocol enabled universal messaging—researchers on different networks could exchange messages regardless of underlying systems, making email truly interoperable.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Reliable asynchronous communication became infrastructure—email became primary coordination tool for distributed research teams and international collaborations.

events.title: ARPANET Adopts TCP/IP
events.description: ARPANET transitions to TCP/IP (January 1, 1983—'flag day'). All connected hosts must switch simultaneously. Creates foundation for modern Internet, enables network-of-networks growth.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Unified protocol enabled internet expansion—research networks worldwide could interconnect using TCP/IP, creating truly global network from regional networks.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Interoperability broke institutional barriers—universities, government labs, and companies could collaborate through shared network infrastructure.

events.title: PCR Invented
events.description: Kary Mullis invents polymerase chain reaction at Cetus Corporation—exponential DNA amplification using primers and heat-stable polymerase. New York Times: 'Divided biology into epochs of before PCR and after PCR.' Enables genomics, forensics, diagnostics. Patent sold to Roche for $300M. Mullis receives 1993 Nobel Prize.

protocolEffects.Inference: DNA amplification from tiny samples revolutionized biology—researchers could analyze genetic material from single cells, ancient specimens, or crime scenes, making molecular biology applicable to previously impossible sources.
protocolEffects.Quality: Exponential amplification enabled verification—any lab with thermocycler could amplify and sequence DNA samples, making genetic findings reproducible across institutions with simple equipment.

events.title: MATLAB Released
events.description: Cleve Moler releases MATLAB—accessible programming environment for matrix computations and numerical analysis. Becomes ubiquitous in engineering and scientific research for simulation, modeling, and data analysis.

protocolEffects.Inference: High-level matrix operations simplified numerical computing—researchers could express algorithms mathematically rather than managing low-level programming details, making computational methods more accessible.

events.title: Macintosh Computer Released
events.description: Apple releases Macintosh (January 24, 1984) with graphical user interface, mouse, and integrated design. Makes computing accessible to non-technical researchers through visual metaphors (desktop, folders, trash).

protocolEffects.Inference: Graphical interface lowered computing barrier—point-and-click interaction made software accessible to researchers without command-line expertise, expanding who could use computational tools.
protocolEffects.Preservation: WYSIWYG document creation enabled visual preservation—researchers could see exactly how documents would appear when printed, improving control over published materials.

events.title: LaTeX Document System
events.description: Leslie Lamport releases LaTeX built on TeX—standardized document preparation system with predefined templates. Becomes universal format for scientific papers, theses, and books with mathematical notation.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Standard document format ensured long-term readability—LaTeX files remained compilable decades later, unlike proprietary word processor formats that became obsolete.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Templates standardized scientific communication—researchers could focus on content while LaTeX handled formatting, ensuring papers met journal requirements automatically.

events.title: Microsoft Windows 1.0 Released
events.description: Microsoft releases Windows 1.0 (November 20, 1985) bringing graphical interface to IBM-compatible PCs. Standardizes user-friendly computing for research applications on dominant PC platform.

protocolEffects.Inference: GUI on PC platform expanded accessibility—graphical interface made computing tools available to researchers using IBM-compatible hardware, democratizing beyond Apple users.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Windows standardization created common platform—software and data formats became more portable across majority of research institutions using PC architecture.

events.title: Human Genome Project Planning Begins
events.description: Santa Fe workshop (March) organized by DOE's Charles DeLisi initiates HGP planning. Dulbecco publishes Science essay proposing whole genome sequencing. Multiple coordination workshops follow. DeLisi's actions launch project, leading to Reagan's 1988 budget line item.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Big biology coordination emerged—demonstrated life sciences could organize multi-billion dollar, multi-decade projects like physics had done with particle accelerators.
protocolEffects.Inference: Shifted biology toward data generation at scale—sequencing entire genome required industrial approach to experimentation, transforming molecular biology toward high-throughput methods.

events.title: Mathematica Released
events.description: Stephen Wolfram releases Mathematica—symbolic computation system integrating calculation, visualization, and documentation. Combines numeric and symbolic math in single environment for technical computing.

protocolEffects.Inference: Symbolic computation enabled mathematical discovery—system could manipulate equations algebraically, solve problems symbolically, and generate insights through computational exploration.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Notebook format integrated code and results—calculations, visualizations, and narrative combined in single document, preserving complete analytical workflow.

events.title: NSFNet Connects Universities
events.description: National Science Foundation network connects universities at T1 speeds (1.5 Mbps). Creates backbone for academic Internet access across America. Enables high-speed data transfer and remote collaboration.

protocolEffects.Engagement: High-speed network enabled data-intensive collaboration—researchers could transfer large datasets between institutions, making distributed computational science practical.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Academic internet backbone connected research community—NSFNet unified American universities into networked research infrastructure, accelerating collaborative projects.

events.title: Cold Fusion Controversy
events.description: Pons and Fleischmann announce room-temperature fusion without peer review, then fail to replicate. Media announcement before publication, lack of controls, and evasiveness exposed quality failures.

events.title: Tim Berners-Lee WWW Proposal
events.description: Berners-Lee submits 'Information Management: A Proposal' on March 12 at CERN describing hypertext system to link information across computers. Manager calls it 'vague, but exciting.' Redistributed 1990, formalized with Cailliau November 1990. Server and browser operational by end of 1990. CERN releases to public domain April 1993.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Hypertext linking revolutionized knowledge navigation—clickable references let researchers follow connections between documents instantly, transforming literature discovery from linear to networked.
protocolEffects.Preservation: URL addressing made documents globally accessible—any web server could host content retrievable worldwide, decentralizing knowledge distribution beyond institutional publishers.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Public domain release enabled rapid adoption—free access to web technology let institutions worldwide build infrastructure without licensing barriers, accelerating network effects.

events.title: arXiv Preprint Server
events.description: Paul Ginsparg launches arXiv.org (originally xxx.lanl.gov) on August 14 for physicists to share preprints via email and FTP. Bypassed 6-month journal review delays. By 1991, 100+ submissions monthly. Now hosts 2M+ papers across physics, math, CS, and biology.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Created permanent, timestamped public record outside publisher control—researchers owned their work, couldn't be censored or paywalled after posting.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Instant global distribution replaced journal delays—discoveries shared within hours of completion, enabling real-time collaboration and priority establishment.

events.title: Human Genome Project Officially Launched
events.description: DOE and NIH formally begin 13-year, $3B project on October 1 to sequence entire human genome. 1988 Memorandum of Understanding sets launch date and 2005 completion target. Unprecedented big science coordination—international collaboration across 20 institutions, standardized data sharing protocols, ELSI program for ethical/legal/social implications.

protocolEffects.Coordination: International consortium coordinated massive biology project—20 institutions across 6 countries worked toward common goal with data sharing agreements, demonstrating global coordination at genomic scale.
protocolEffects.Inference: Industrial-scale sequencing transformed biology—automated high-throughput methods replaced artisanal approaches, making data generation rather than hypothesis-testing the bottleneck.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Mandated public data release created open genomic resource—all sequences deposited in GenBank within 24 hours, establishing immediate public access as norm for big science data.

events.title: Baltimore Affair
events.description: NIH accuses Thereza Imanishi-Kari of data fabrication in Cell paper co-authored with David Baltimore. Congressional investigation exposes institutional conflicts in handling fraud allegations.

events.title: World Wide Web
events.description: Tim Berners-Lee releases first web server and browser to public in August 1991. Hypertext links connected documents across computers worldwide. CERN makes it public domain in April 1993, enabling explosive growth to millions of sites.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Hyperlinks created interconnected knowledge network—researchers could discover related work by following links rather than manual citation searches, exponentially increasing discoverability.
protocolEffects.Preservation: URLs made any document globally addressable and accessible—knowledge could be referenced and retrieved from anywhere, not just institutional libraries.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Researchers could publish findings instantly to global audience without publishers—direct communication enabled rapid collaboration and reduced institutional gatekeeping.

events.title: Linux Kernel Released
events.description: Linus Torvalds posts to comp.os.minix on August 25 announcing 'free operating system (just a hobby).' Releases version 0.02 October 5. Open source collaborative development model—12,000+ developers from 1,200+ companies eventually contribute. All 500 most powerful supercomputers now run Linux. Foundation for scientific computing infrastructure.

protocolEffects.Inference: Open source OS democratized computing infrastructure—researchers could customize operating system for scientific needs without proprietary constraints, enabling specialized computational environments.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Collaborative development model proved distributed teams could build complex systems—thousands of contributors coordinated through email and version control, pioneering open source governance.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Free software ensured long-term availability—Linux couldn't be discontinued by vendor, making scientific computing infrastructure sustainable independent of commercial decisions.

events.title: Mosaic Web Browser Released
events.description: NCSA releases Mosaic browser (April 1993) with inline images and point-and-click navigation. First graphical web browser makes WWW accessible beyond technical users. Downloads reach 2M by 1994.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Graphical browser made web accessible to non-technical researchers—inline images and intuitive navigation eliminated command-line barriers, catalyzing web adoption for scientific communication.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Visual web presentation enabled rich documentation—researchers could publish figures, data visualizations, and formatted text directly online, expanding beyond plain text sharing.

events.title: Computational Reproducibility Crisis Identified
events.description: Buckheit & Donoho demonstrate computational research is irreproducible without complete software environments and source code. 'An article about computational results is advertising, not scholarship.'

events.title: PubMed Database Launched
events.description: National Library of Medicine launches PubMed providing free web-based access to MEDLINE biomedical literature database. Transforms how researchers discover scientific papers—searches return results instantly from millions of citations.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Free web access democratized literature search—any researcher worldwide could search biomedical literature without institutional subscriptions or database fees.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Centralized index made scattered literature discoverable—PubMed unified access to thousands of journals, preventing important research from being lost in publication volume.

events.title: Google Search Founded
events.description: Larry Page and Sergey Brin launch Google with PageRank algorithm ranking pages by link importance. Revolutionizes information discovery—becomes primary tool for finding scientific literature and data online.

protocolEffects.Engagement: PageRank made web content discoverable—algorithm surfaced authoritative sources based on citation-like linking, making scattered online research findable through simple searches.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Web indexing preserved discoverability—Google cached and indexed pages, making content accessible even if original sites went offline temporarily.

events.title: SETI@Home Distributed Computing
events.description: UC Berkeley launches SETI@Home—volunteers download screensaver that analyzes radio telescope data during idle time. Thousands of personal computers contribute processing power. Pioneers crowdsourced scientific computation model.

protocolEffects.Inference: Distributed computing enabled massive parallel analysis—harnessing idle CPU cycles from volunteers provided computational power matching supercomputers at fraction of cost.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Volunteer participation democratized contribution—anyone could donate computing resources to science, creating new form of public engagement beyond traditional citizen science.

events.title: Digital Object Identifier (DOI)
events.description: International DOI Foundation establishes persistent identifier system for digital objects. Publishers assign DOIs to papers—permanent identifiers that resolve to current URLs even if locations change.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Persistent identifiers solved link rot—DOIs remained constant even when publishers moved content, ensuring citations stayed valid long-term.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Standardized citation enabled automated tracking—DOIs provided machine-readable identifiers for linking publications, datasets, and citations systematically.

events.title: PubMed Central Launched
events.description: NIH establishes PubMed Central as free digital archive of biomedical and life sciences literature. Creates infrastructure for public access to federally funded research. Voluntary deposit initially, becomes mandatory 2008.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Free digital archive preserved research outside publisher control—NIH hosted permanent copies ensuring public access survived publisher business changes.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Open access removed paywalls for deposited papers—anyone could read federally funded research without subscriptions, expanding access beyond wealthy institutions.

events.title: Creative Commons
events.description: Creative Commons organization launches with flexible copyright licenses. Enables creators to specify sharing permissions (attribution, non-commercial, derivatives, etc.) rather than all-rights-reserved default.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Flexible licensing enabled legal sharing—researchers could explicitly permit reuse while retaining attribution rights, making open sharing legally clear.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Standardized licenses clarified reuse terms—CC licenses provided machine-readable permissions, enabling automated discovery of reusable content.

events.title: Wikipedia Founded
events.description: Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger launch Wikipedia (January 15, 2001)—collaborative online encyclopedia anyone can edit. Reaches 1M articles by 2006. Demonstrates open peer production and becomes major reference for scientific topics.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Collaborative editing enabled distributed knowledge creation—thousands of contributors could build comprehensive encyclopedia without central editorial control, demonstrating peer production at scale.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Version history preserved complete edit record—every change tracked and revertible, creating transparent knowledge evolution different from static encyclopedias.

events.title: DSpace Repository Platform
events.description: MIT and Hewlett-Packard release DSpace—first widely adopted open-source platform for institutional repositories. Enables universities to preserve and provide access to their research output. Becomes standard for academic digital archives.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Institutional repositories enabled local preservation—universities could archive their own research output in sustainable systems, reducing dependence on commercial publishers for long-term access.

events.title: BOINC Platform Released
events.description: Berkeley releases Open Infrastructure for Network Computing (BOINC)—generalizes distributed computing model from SETI@Home. Any scientific project can harness volunteer computing power worldwide. Supports climate modeling, protein folding, mathematics research.

protocolEffects.Inference: Platform democratized supercomputing access—research projects could access massive computational power through volunteers, making resource-intensive analysis possible without expensive infrastructure.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Volunteer computing created participatory science—public could contribute directly to research through donated CPU cycles, engaging non-specialists in scientific computation.

events.title: Schön Bell Labs Superconductivity Fraud
events.description: Jan Hendrik Schön fabricated data in 16 of 24 investigated papers. Nature retracts 7 papers, Science 8, Physical Review 6. PhD revoked. Most extensive physics fraud in modern history.

events.title: Human Genome Project Completion
events.description: Human Genome Project completes full sequence (April 14, 2003)—99% of gene-containing regions at 99.99% accuracy. Massive international collaboration demonstrates new scales of coordinated research and data-driven discovery.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Demonstrated biology could execute decade-long coordinated projects—proved life sciences could organize at scales previously seen only in physics, establishing big biology model.
protocolEffects.Inference: Complete genome enabled systems biology—having full genetic code transformed biology from studying individual genes to analyzing whole genomes and networks.

events.title: Budapest Open Access Initiative
events.description: International meeting (December 2001, declaration February 2002) defines open access principles: free online access, unrestricted use, permanent archiving. Soros Foundation funds initiative. Launches global OA movement.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Formalized open access goals—clear definition and strategies gave researchers shared vocabulary and objectives for changing publishing system.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Established archiving as OA requirement—open access meant not just free reading but permanent preservation, ensuring long-term availability.

events.title: PLOS ONE Launches
events.description: PLOS launches megajournal (December 2006, backdated conception) reviewing for soundness only, not significance. Accepts technically correct research regardless of perceived impact. Challenges traditional journal selectivity, reaches 30,000+ papers/year by 2013.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Soundness-only review reduced publication barriers—methodologically sound work could be published even if deemed 'unexciting,' making more research accessible.
protocolEffects.Quality: Shifted evaluation post-publication—community could judge significance after reading rather than editors gatekeeping pre-publication, distributing quality assessment.

events.title: NIH Voluntary Public Access Policy
events.description: National Institutes of Health encourages researchers to deposit papers in PubMed Central within 12 months of publication. Voluntary policy begins federal OA push. Becomes mandatory in 2008 after low voluntary compliance (<4%).

protocolEffects.Engagement: Policy began federal open access requirements—established principle that taxpayer-funded research should be publicly accessible, pressuring publishers to accept deposit.
protocolEffects.Preservation: PubMed Central deposits created public archive—papers preserved outside publisher control, ensuring long-term access independent of subscription changes.

events.title: Ioannidis: Most Research Findings Are False
events.description: John Ioannidis publishes landmark paper in PLOS Medicine arguing that for most study designs, research claims are more likely false than true due to bias, small sample sizes, and flexible analysis methods.

events.title: Git Version Control Created
events.description: Linus Torvalds creates Git in April 2005—distributed version control system for Linux kernel development. Every contributor has complete repository copy. Cryptographic hashing ensures integrity. Becomes foundation for GitHub and modern collaborative development.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Distributed version control made every version permanent—complete history preserved cryptographically in multiple copies, enabling perfect reconstruction of any past state.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Branching and merging enabled parallel work—multiple developers could work independently then integrate changes, revolutionizing collaborative code development.

events.title: Hwang Stem Cell Fraud
events.description: Seoul National University confirms Hwang Woo-suk's human stem cell cloning was entirely fabricated. Science retracts both papers. Described as most significant fraud since Piltdown Man.

events.title: Amazon Web Services Launches
events.description: Amazon launches EC2 and S3 cloud services (August 2006)—on-demand computing and storage rentable by the hour. Democratizes access to massive computational and storage resources for research without capital investment.

protocolEffects.Inference: On-demand computing democratized access—researchers could rent supercomputer-scale resources by hour, making massive computations accessible without capital investment.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Cloud storage provided scalable archives—researchers could store datasets at scale with reliability guarantees, though vendor lock-in created preservation risks.

events.title: Zotero Reference Manager
events.description: Roy Rosenzweig Center releases Zotero—free open-source tool for collecting, organizing, and citing research sources. Browser extension captures citations with one click. Generates bibliographies automatically in any format.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Free reference management democratized citation organization—researchers could build personal libraries without expensive commercial software.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Browser integration automated citation capture—one-click saving from web pages made literature collection effortless, improving research organization.

events.title: Google Docs Launched
events.description: Google releases web-based collaborative document editing (acquired Writely March 2006). Enables multiple researchers to write and edit documents simultaneously in real-time. Auto-saves and tracks changes.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Real-time collaboration enabled simultaneous editing—multiple authors could write together live, transforming collaborative writing from serial to parallel process.
protocolEffects.Inference: Web-based tools eliminated software barriers—any researcher with browser could access documents, making collaboration platform-independent.

events.title: Bitcoin Blockchain Released
events.description: Satoshi Nakamoto releases Bitcoin whitepaper (October 31, 2008) and software (January 3, 2009). Introduces blockchain technology—distributed, cryptographically-secured ledger. Demonstrates decentralized consensus without central authority. Inspires decentralized infrastructure for science.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Blockchain demonstrated cryptographic preservation—distributed ledger showed how decentralized networks could maintain permanent tamper-proof records without central authority.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Decentralized consensus proved coordination without institutions—inspired thinking about distributed scientific governance, attribution, and funding systems.

events.title: GitHub Launch
events.description: Tom Preston-Werner, Chris Wanstrath, and PJ Hyett launch GitHub in April as web-based Git hosting. Add pull requests, issue tracking, and social features to Linus Torvalds' distributed version control. Reaches 100M+ repositories by 2018, becomes default platform for open source and scientific code.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Git's cryptographic hashing made every code version permanent and tamper-proof—complete history preserved in distributed copies across thousands of machines, no single point of failure.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Pull request model enabled anyone to propose changes to any public project—lowered collaboration barrier from 'know the maintainer' to 'fork and submit'.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Contribution graphs and commit attribution automatically tracked who did what when—micro-contributions became visible, replacing binary authorship with granular credit.

events.title: Dryad Digital Repository
events.description: Dryad launches as curated repository for research data underlying scientific publications. Makes datasets discoverable, citable with DOIs, and permanently archived. Integrated with journal submission workflows.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Research data repository made datasets citable—underlying data could be published with DOIs alongside papers, enabling reuse and verification beyond narrative descriptions.

events.title: NIH Mandatory Public Access Policy
events.description: NIH mandates all funded research be openly accessible within 12 months (enacted April 2008). Transforms voluntary 2004 policy to requirement after <4% compliance. Establishes precedent for federal OA mandates.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Mandatory deposit transformed OA from voluntary to required—NIH grantees had to make papers publicly accessible, establishing enforceable open access.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Required archiving ensured preservation—all NIH-funded research preserved in PubMed Central regardless of journal, creating comprehensive public biomedical archive.

events.title: Mendeley Reference Manager
events.description: Mendeley launches combining reference management with social networking. Researchers can organize citations, discover papers through recommendations, and connect with colleagues reading similar work.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Social reference management combined organization with discovery—researchers could build libraries while seeing what peers were reading.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Research networking features connected scholars—profile pages and paper recommendations created academic social network around literature sharing.

events.title: Dropbox Cloud Storage
events.description: Dropbox launches user-friendly cloud file synchronization and storage (September 2008). Files automatically sync across devices. Enables researchers to access and share files across devices and with collaborators through shared folders.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Automatic cloud sync simplified backup—files backed up continuously to cloud, reducing data loss from hardware failures.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Shared folders enabled file collaboration—teams could work on same datasets with automatic synchronization, simplifying distributed research.

events.title: Climategate Email Controversy
events.description: Hacked emails from Climate Research Unit spark allegations of peer review manipulation and data suppression. Though investigations found no misconduct, controversy damaged public trust in climate science.

events.title: Retraction Watch Founded
events.description: Science writers Ivan Oransky and Adam Marcus launch Retraction Watch blog in August, tracking retractions as 'window into scientific process.' Expose that retractions aren't announced and reasons unpublicized. Create transparency in research integrity. Database now tracks 50,000+ retractions.

protocolEffects.Quality: Public tracking exposed retraction scale—transparent database revealed extent of scientific integrity issues, creating accountability through visibility and systematic documentation.

events.title: Arsenic Life Paper Published
events.description: NASA announces bacteria using arsenic instead of phosphorus with media fanfare. Immediate criticism, failed replications, eventually retracted 2025. Exposed peer review and press release failures.

events.title: Sci-Hub Founded
events.description: Alexandra Elbakyan creates Sci-Hub on September 5 in Kazakhstan at age 23, providing free access to paywalled research papers. Response to rising journal costs blocking researchers. Grows to largest open knowledge platform in history with 64M+ papers. 2016 Nature 'top 10 people who mattered.'

protocolEffects.Engagement: Pirate library demonstrated massive unmet demand—millions of researchers worldwide used Sci-Hub to access paywalled papers, exposing how subscription system blocked knowledge access even at wealthy institutions.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Centralized repository preserved papers outside publisher control—created comprehensive backup of scholarly literature independent of commercial interests, though through copyright violation.

events.title: Stapel Psychology Fraud Exposed
events.description: Diederik Stapel suspended for fabricating data in 58+ publications over years. PhD students discover fraud. Described as 'biggest con man in academic science,' exposing systemic peer review failure.

events.title: Replication Crisis
events.description: Recognition of reproducibility failures exposed fundamental flaws in centralized peer review—the beginning of Quality's digital-native rebuilding.

events.title: Zoom Video Conferencing
events.description: Eric Yuan launches Zoom providing cloud-based video conferencing. Becomes critical infrastructure for remote research collaboration, especially during COVID-19 pandemic. Enables distributed teams to meet face-to-face virtually.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Cloud video conferencing enabled distributed meetings—research teams could collaborate face-to-face without travel, reducing coordination costs and enabling global participation.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Screen sharing facilitated remote presentations—researchers could demonstrate data, code, and results to distant collaborators in real-time.

events.title: Figshare Repository
events.description: Figshare launches as repository for all research outputs—datasets, figures, posters, negative results, code. Makes everything citable with DOIs. Preserves research artifacts beyond traditional papers.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Repository for all outputs made negative results and datasets citable—expanded what counted as preservable scholarly contribution beyond papers alone.
protocolEffects.Engagement: DOI assignment for figures and datasets enabled micro-publication—researchers could share and cite individual results, increasing granularity of scholarly record.

events.title: Elsevier Boycott Begins
events.description: Researchers began organizing boycott of Elsevier over high prices and restrictive policies, exposing publisher monopoly tensions.

events.title: Amgen Cancer Reproducibility Failure
events.description: Amgen scientists could replicate only 6 of 53 'landmark' cancer studies, exposing systemic reproducibility failure in biomedical research. Published in Nature by Begley & Ellis.

events.title: Cost of Knowledge Petition
events.description: Over 17,000 researchers pledged to boycott Elsevier journals, catalyzing open access advocacy and publisher reform pressure.

events.title: Retraction Surge: Misconduct Dominates
events.description: Study of 2,047 retracted biomedical articles finds 67% due to misconduct (fraud, plagiarism, duplication), only 21% from error. Retractions increased 10-fold over previous decade.

events.title: Serials Crisis Peaks
events.description: Journal subscription costs rise 273% since 1986 while library budgets stagnate, forcing mass cancellations and limiting researcher access to published knowledge.

events.title: ORCID Launched
events.description: ORCID (Open Researcher and Contributor ID) launches October 16, 2012. Provides persistent unique identifiers for researchers (16-digit numbers). Solves name ambiguity problem—distinguishes researchers with common names across career moves and name changes.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Unique researcher IDs solved name ambiguity—persistent identifiers distinguished researchers with common names, enabling accurate attribution across careers, institutions, and name changes.

events.title: Experiment.com Founded
events.description: Denny Luan and Cindy Wu launch first dedicated crowdfunding platform for scientific research in May (originally Microryza, renamed 2014). All-or-nothing funding model, backers participate in scientific process. Funds 80+ projects, raises $600K+ by 2014.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Crowdfunding created alternative funding mechanism—researchers could pitch directly to public, bypassing traditional grant systems for pilot funding.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Public participation in funding decisions—backers could support research they cared about, democratizing some resource allocation beyond peer review panels.

events.title: Overleaf Collaborative LaTeX
events.description: Overleaf (originally WriteLaTeX) launches as collaborative cloud-based LaTeX editor. Multiple authors can edit same document simultaneously. Real-time preview, version history, templates. Makes technical writing collaborative.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Cloud-based LaTeX enabled real-time collaborative writing—multiple authors could edit technical documents simultaneously, combining LaTeX power with Google Docs-style collaboration.
protocolEffects.Inference: Eliminated local setup barriers—researchers could write papers in browser without installing LaTeX distribution, lowering technical barriers to professional typesetting.

events.title: Obama Open Access Directive
events.description: White House OSTP memo (February 22, 2013) requires all federal agencies with $100M+ research budgets to mandate public access to publications and data. Expands OA beyond NIH to NSF, DOE, NASA, and other agencies.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Federal mandate dramatically expanded OA requirements—researchers across sciences had to make work publicly accessible, accelerating open access transition beyond biomedical fields.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Coordinated federal preservation—multiple agencies archiving research created distributed backup system for federally funded science.

events.title: bioRxiv Preprint Server
events.description: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory launches bioRxiv (November 2013) extending preprint model from physics to biology. Enables rapid sharing of life sciences research before peer review. Growth accelerates during COVID-19.
