protocolEffects.Engagement: Biology preprints accelerated discovery communication—life scientists could share findings immediately like physicists had done since 1991, reducing publication delays from months to days.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Permanent preprint archive established priority—biologists could timestamp findings publicly before journal publication, protecting discovery credit during long review.

events.title: Open Science Framework (OSF)
events.description: Center for Open Science launches OSF providing free infrastructure for study preregistration, data storage, and project management. Improves research transparency and reproducibility through integrated workflow platform.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Integrated platform unified research workflow—preregistration, data storage, and collaboration in single system simplified transparency practices.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Permanent timestamps for preregistrations—locked study plans provided verifiable record preventing post-hoc hypothesizing and p-hacking.
protocolEffects.Quality: Preregistration reduced publication bias—registered studies committed to publishing regardless of results, combating file-drawer problem of unpublished negative findings.

events.title: Slack Team Communication
events.description: Slack launches (August 2013) providing channel-based messaging and file sharing. Becomes widely adopted for research team coordination and real-time collaboration. Searchable message history organizes communications.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Channel-based communication organized team discussions—topic-specific channels kept conversations searchable and organized, improving on scattered email threads.

events.title: Zenodo Research Repository
events.description: CERN and OpenAIRE launch Zenodo providing free repository infrastructure for all research outputs with DOI assignment, long-term preservation, and version control. CERN backing ensures institutional sustainability commitment.

protocolEffects.Preservation: CERN-hosted repository provided trusted long-term storage—research outputs preserved with version control and DOIs, backed by institutional commitment to sustainability independent of commercial pressures.

events.title: Gridcoin Cryptocurrency
events.description: Gridcoin launches (October 16) as the first successful implementation tying electrical energy utilized for scientific computation to monetary value. Participants earn currency by contributing processing power to BOINC distributed science projects including protein folding, climate modeling, and astronomical data analysis.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Novel incentive mechanism aligned computational resources with scientific contribution—created economic infrastructure where energy expenditure directly advanced research through verifiable proof-of-research.
protocolEffects.Inference: Distributed computing gained sustainable funding model—researchers could access global volunteer processing power for computationally intensive analysis through aligned economic incentives.

events.title: Clinical Trials Unreported Crisis
events.description: BMJ study finds 50% of clinical trials never published, trials with negative results twice as likely unreported. AllTrials campaign launches. Doctors making decisions on partial, biased evidence.

events.title: MySpace Data Loss
events.description: Platform migration corrupts server data, deleting 50+ million songs and photos uploaded 2003-2015. Demonstrates fragility of platform-dependent preservation.

events.title: Registered Reports Format
events.description: Cortex journal introduces Registered Reports publication format. Study designs are peer-reviewed before data collection. Accepted protocols guaranteed publication regardless of results. Reduces publication bias and improves research quality.

protocolEffects.Quality: Pre-registration of study design reduced bias—peer review before data collection prevented p-hacking, HARKing, and post-hoc hypothesizing, improving methodological rigor.

events.title: Research Data Unavailability Crisis
events.description: Vines et al. study in Current Biology finds 80% of research data is lost within 20 years of publication due to obsolete storage devices and defunct email addresses.

events.title: STAP Cell Scandal
events.description: Nature retracts stem cell papers after fabrication discovered, exposing peer review's failure to detect fraud. Investigation reveals data falsification, co-author suicide follows.

events.title: NIH Funding Success Rate Collapses
events.description: NIH grant success rate drops to 18%, with 82% of applications rejected. Perverse incentives intensify as researchers compete for scarce resources.

events.title: Facebook Emotional Contagion Ethics Scandal
events.description: Facebook manipulates 700,000 users' news feeds without consent for psychological research. Published in PNAS, exposing gaps in research ethics oversight for digital platforms.

events.title: Harvard Link Rot Study
events.description: Harvard Law Review study finds over 70% of URLs in legal journals and 50% in Supreme Court opinions suffer reference rot—cited information no longer accessible.

events.title: Jupyter Project Launched
events.description: IPython Notebook evolves into Project Jupyter, spun off by Fernando Pérez and 6 founding members. Supports 100+ languages, enables reproducible computational notebooks integrating code, data, and narrative. 2021 Nature names it one of ten computing projects that transformed science.

protocolEffects.Inference: Computational notebooks integrated code, data, and narrative—enabled reproducible analysis where methods, results, and interpretation lived together in executable documents.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Notebook format preserved complete workflow—entire analysis pipeline saved in single file making computational research reproducible and shareable.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Interactive documents enabled exploration—readers could rerun analyses with different parameters, transforming papers from static descriptions to executable investigations.

events.title: Docker Containerization Released
events.description: Docker becomes widely adopted for packaging computational environments. Containers bundle code with dependencies and system libraries. Makes research reproducible across different computing systems—'it works on my machine' problem solved.

protocolEffects.Inference: Containers packaged complete computational environments—code plus all dependencies bundled together, making complex analyses portable across different systems and cloud platforms.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Containerized software preserved executability—frozen environments ensured code would run identically years later despite operating system changes and dependency updates.

events.title: Theranos Fraud Investigation Begins
events.description: WSJ investigation exposes fake blood testing technology. Theranos using commercial analyzers, tampering with data. Regulatory crackdown follows. Holmes eventually convicted of fraud.

events.title: Gates Foundation Open Access Policy
events.description: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation mandates immediate open access for all funded research (January 1, 2015) with CC-BY license. Strongest OA policy from major funder—no embargo periods, requires liberal reuse rights.

protocolEffects.Engagement: Immediate OA with permissive licensing pressured publishers—Gates funding influence forced journals to accept open terms, demonstrating funder power to reshape publishing.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Required repository deposit with liberal licensing—research preserved in multiple open archives with rights enabling reuse, remix, and redistribution.

events.title: LaCour Gay Marriage Study Fabrication
events.description: UCLA grad student Michael LaCour fabricates entire dataset for Science paper. No survey conducted, funding sources fake. Grad students uncover fraud attempting replication. Retracted after 5 months.

events.title: Psychology Replication Project Failure
events.description: Open Science Collaboration replicates 100 psychology studies—only 36% successfully replicate. 97% of originals were significant, only 36% of replications. Exposes reproducibility crisis depth.

events.title: Apple ResearchKit Released
events.description: Apple launches open-source ResearchKit framework on March 9, enabling medical researchers to create iPhone apps for large-scale health studies. mPower Parkinson's app enrolls 10,000+ participants—largest Parkinson's study in history, 93% never participated in research before.

protocolEffects.Inference: Smartphone-based studies enabled massive enrollment—health research apps recruited thousands in days, scaling far beyond traditional clinical trial logistics.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Direct participant recruitment bypassed institutions—researchers could reach participants globally through app stores, democratizing study access.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Participants accessed their own data—transparency in data collection built trust and enabled personal health tracking alongside research contribution.

events.title: IPFS Protocol
events.description: InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) introduces content-addressed storage. Files identified by cryptographic hash rather than location. Enables decentralized, censorship-resistant, permanent knowledge preservation.

protocolEffects.Preservation: Content addressing made files location-independent—files identified by cryptographic hash survived server changes and deletions, enabling permanent web vision.

events.title: AlphaGo Defeats Lee Sedol
events.description: DeepMind's AlphaGo wins 4-1 against 9-dan professional Lee Sedol in Seoul (March 2016), watched by 200M+ people. First AI to beat human Go champion without handicap. Combines deep neural networks with reinforcement learning. Hassabis and Jumper later win 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for applying techniques to AlphaFold.

protocolEffects.Inference: AI surpassing humans demonstrated machine intelligence—deep learning proved capable of intuition and strategic creativity in complex domains, not just calculation, foreshadowing AI's role in scientific discovery.

events.title: FAIR Data Principles Published
events.description: Wilkinson et al. publish in Nature Scientific Data on March 15. Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles for scientific data management. Stakeholders from academia, industry, funding agencies endorse. Emphasizes machine-actionable data. Becomes international standard.

protocolEffects.Preservation: FAIR principles standardized data management—concrete guidelines for making data useful beyond original study, ensuring datasets remained findable and reusable long-term.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Machine-actionable emphasis enabled automation—structured data could be discovered and integrated computationally, not just read by humans, enabling large-scale data synthesis.
protocolEffects.Coordination: International consensus created shared standards—stakeholders across sectors agreed on data principles, enabling coordinated implementation across repositories and institutions.

events.title: npm left-pad Crisis
events.description: Developer removes 11-line package from npm, breaking thousands of projects including React, Babel, Webpack. Exposes fragility of dependency-based computational infrastructure.

events.title: ASA P-Hacking Statement
events.description: American Statistical Association issues first-ever position statement on p-value misuse. Responds to widespread statistical manipulation, cherry-picking, and significance chasing epidemic.

events.title: Nature Reproducibility Survey
events.description: Survey of 1,500 scientists reveals 70% failed to reproduce another's experiments, 50% couldn't reproduce their own. Over half agree there's a reproducibility crisis.

events.title: AsPredicted Preregistration
events.description: AsPredicted.org launches as simple preregistration platform for research studies. Nine-question web form timestamps hypotheses and analysis plans before seeing data. Makes preregistration quick and accessible.

protocolEffects.Quality: Simple preregistration removed friction—quick web form made study pre-commitment accessible, increasing researcher adoption of transparency practices beyond complex OSF workflows.

events.title: Microsoft Teams Launched
events.description: Microsoft releases Teams (March 2017) as integrated collaboration platform. Combines chat, video conferencing, file sharing, and Office integration. Becomes widely adopted for research team coordination within Microsoft ecosystem.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Integrated collaboration platform unified communication—chat, video, and files in single system simplified team coordination, especially for institutions using Microsoft infrastructure.

events.title: CRISPR Patent Battle
events.description: UC Berkeley vs Broad Institute patent dispute over CRISPR exposes broken credit attribution. Competing claims over who invented gene editing highlight coordination system's inability to properly attribute collaborative discoveries.

events.title: Citation Cartels Exposed
events.description: SAGE retracts 60 papers in Journal of Vibration and Control after 14-month investigation uncovers citation ring and fake peer review. Authors suggest fake reviewers to write their own reviews.

events.title: Elsevier Acquires bePress
events.description: Major commercial publisher acquires institutional repository platform, raising concerns about control over open access infrastructure and scholarly workflow. Libraries feel betrayed.

events.title: Sci-Hub Reaches 64 Million Papers
events.description: Pirate repository demonstrated massive demand for open access, exposing paywalled research system's failures.

events.title: Grievance Studies Hoax
events.description: Boghossian, Lindsay, and Pluckrose submit 20 bogus papers to peer-reviewed journals—7 accepted, 4 published—exposing collapsed review standards. One paper plagiarized Mein Kampf.

events.title: Retraction Watch Database Launch
events.description: Database documents 18,000+ retractions. Study reveals retraction rates doubled 2003-2009. Systematic documentation of quality failures across disciplines.

events.title: Wansink Food Psychology Misconduct
events.description: Cornell finds Brian Wansink committed misconduct through p-hacking and statistical manipulation. 18 papers retracted. Blog post exposed 'data dredging' practices. Forced to resign.

events.title: MDPI Nutrients Mass Resignation
events.description: 10 senior editors including editor-in-chief resign from MDPI journal, alleging pressure to accept mediocre papers and replace leadership for maintaining high editorial standards.

events.title: ResearchGate Copyright Lawsuit
events.description: Elsevier and ACS sue ResearchGate alleging 7 million copyright violations. Years of litigation expose tensions between open sharing and publisher control.

events.title: Plan S Backlash
events.description: Open access mandate sparks controversy—1,400+ scientists sign letter calling it 'too risky' and violation of academic freedom. 85% of journals non-compliant. Implementation delayed.

events.title: Plan S Announced
events.description: European research funders coalition (cOAlition S) announces Plan S (September 4, 2018). Mandates immediate open access for funded research starting 2021—no embargo periods. Accelerates global transition from subscription publishing.

protocolEffects.Engagement: European funder mandate accelerated OA transition—immediate open access requirement pressured publishers to transform business models or lose European authors.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Required compliant repositories—ensured research preserved in sustainable open archives with liberal licensing, not just temporarily made free.

events.title: GPT-2 Released
events.description: OpenAI releases 1.5B parameter language model in February, trained on 40GB Internet text. Staged release due to misuse concerns—full model November 5. Demonstrates unsupervised multitask learning—translation, summarization, question-answering without fine-tuning. Foreshadows transformation of scientific writing.

protocolEffects.Inference: Large language model demonstrated unsupervised learning—AI trained on text alone could perform multiple tasks without task-specific training, showing emergence of general capabilities from scale.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Text generation capabilities foreshadowed AI writing assistance—early demonstration of AI's potential to assist scientific communication, literature synthesis, and hypothesis generation.

events.title: Academic Job Market Collapse
events.description: Less than 17% of STEM PhDs find tenure-track positions within 3 years. PhD production vastly exceeds available positions, coordination system failing entire generation of researchers.

events.title: University of California Cancels Elsevier
events.description: Largest US university system dropped Elsevier subscriptions over pricing, demonstrating institutional revolt against publisher monopolies.

events.title: Hyperauthorship Crisis
events.description: Physics papers with 5,000+ authors become common. 24 of 33 pages list authors. Authorship inflation makes individual credit attribution impossible, eroding coordination protocol.

events.title: Google+ Shutdown
events.description: Google shuts down Google+ on April 2, deleting all posts, photos, videos, and communities. Platform closure demonstrates URL/platform dependency failure for preserved scientific content and discussions.

events.title: AlphaFold Solves Protein Folding
events.description: DeepMind's AlphaFold2 wins CASP14 competition in December with 92.4 GDT median score, 1.6Å average error—accurate to width of one atom. John Moult: '50-year-old grand challenge has been largely solved.' predicts protein structures in minutes vs years of experimental work. transforms structural biology from experimental bottleneck to computational abundance.

protocolEffects.Inference: AI model trained on existing structures predicted protein folding from sequence alone—computation replaced months of crystallography, making structure prediction accessible to any researcher with sequence data.
protocolEffects.Quality: Predictions verified against experimental structures in blind CASP competition—independent validation showed computational predictions matched lab results, establishing AI as trusted inference method.

events.title: COVID-19 Vaccine Development Acceleration
events.description: Virus sequence published January 10. Prototype vaccines in mice by February 18. mRNA vaccine in clinical trials within 65 days. WHO R&D Blueprint coordinates global response. Public-private partnerships at unprecedented scale—CEPI invests $1.5B in 14 vaccines.

protocolEffects.Coordination: Global coordination enabled unprecedented speed—virus sequence shared globally January 10, WHO R&D Blueprint unified efforts, public-private partnerships mobilized resources at massive scale demonstrating coordinated response capability.
protocolEffects.Inference: Platform technologies accelerated development—pre-existing mRNA technology and computational design enabled rapid vaccine creation once sequence known, validating platform approach to therapeutics.

events.title: Lancet Hydroxychloroquine Retraction
events.description: Lancet retracts COVID-19 study after 13 days when fraudulent Surgisphere data exposed. Peer review failed to detect fabricated dataset affecting global health policy.

events.title: COVID-19 Preprint Surge
events.description: Pandemic urgency accelerated preprint adoption, exposing tensions between speed and quality in centralized publishing—a digital-native alternative emerged.

events.title: Adobe Flash End-of-Life
events.description: Adobe discontinues Flash Player, rendering countless interactive scientific visualizations, educational materials, and research tools permanently inaccessible.

events.title: Zoom Fatigue Crisis
events.description: Pandemic forces virtual collaboration. Studies document exhaustion, burnout, depression from videoconferencing. 'Far more attention-taxing than face-to-face.' Research collaboration suffers.

events.title: COVID Preprint Misinformation Crisis
events.description: Over 350,000 COVID articles and 65,000 preprints published by 2021. Withdrawn bioRxiv preprints promoted widely before retraction. Misinformation spreads before peer review, creating 'infodemic.'

events.title: Graduate Student Mental Health Crisis
events.description: Nature reports depression and anxiety among graduate students at rates 6x higher than general population. Council of Graduate Schools study exposes mental health crisis from publish-or-perish culture and brutal job market.

events.title: Convergent Research Launches FRO Model
events.description: Convergent Research establishes itself as non-profit to incubate Focused Research Organizations—coordinated, medium-sized teams producing public goods like tools and datasets. Fills gap between academic labs and commercial incentives. Enables infrastructure-building projects.

protocolEffects.Coordination: FRO model filled coordination gap—medium-sized teams could tackle tool-building and dataset-creation projects too large for academic labs but not commercially viable.
protocolEffects.Inference: Enabled infrastructure development—FROs could develop enabling technologies (new instruments, methods, databases) that expanded research capabilities without fitting traditional funding models.

events.title: AlphaFold Database Expansion
events.description: DeepMind and EMBL-EBI release 200M+ protein structure predictions on July 28—nearly all catalogued proteins known to science. 200x expansion from 2021 launch (1M to 214M structures). Free, open access database at alphafold.ebi.ac.uk. Transforms structural biology from experimental bottleneck to computational abundance.

protocolEffects.Inference: 200M protein structures transformed biology—computational predictions made structural data abundant, shifting bottleneck from structure determination to functional analysis and enabling proteome-scale investigations.
protocolEffects.Preservation: Free open database democratized access—any researcher could download predicted structures with APIs and bulk downloads, making structural biology accessible beyond experimental crystallography labs.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Programmatic access enabled integration—AlphaFold data could be computationally accessed and incorporated into analysis pipelines, not just individually browsed, enabling systematic structural bioinformatics.

events.title: ChatGPT Released
events.description: OpenAI releases ChatGPT on November 30 based on GPT-3.5 with reinforcement learning from human feedback. Reaches 100M users in 2 months—fastest-growing app ever. Researchers immediately adopt it for literature review, hypothesis generation, writing assistance. Exposes tensions: hallucinated citations (36%), but democratizes AI assistance.

protocolEffects.Inference: Conversational AI democratized computational assistance—researchers could describe problems in natural language and get code, analysis suggestions, and explanations without programming expertise.
protocolEffects.Engagement: AI writing assistance accelerated communication—automated drafting, editing, and summarization sped up paper writing and literature synthesis, though hallucinated citations created verification burden.
protocolEffects.Quality: Hallucination problem exposed AI limitations—36% fake citations revealed AI couldn't be trusted blindly, requiring human verification and creating new quality control challenges.

events.title: Twitter/X Researcher Exodus
events.description: Elon Musk takeover triggers academic exodus. 50% of environmental scientists leave, overall academic engagement drops. Curation team fired, misinformation spreads. Science communication infrastructure collapses.

events.title: Alzheimer's Research Fraud
events.description: Sylvain Lesné's influential 2006 Nature paper on amyloid beta found to have manipulated images. 70+ instances of tampering across 20 papers. 16 years and $287M in NIH funding potentially misdirected.

events.title: Predatory Journal Epidemic
events.description: InterAcademy Partnership reports 15,500+ predatory journals operating. Fake peer review from 'review mills' undermining scholarly integrity. COPE issues guidance.

events.title: ChatGPT Fake Citations Crisis
events.description: Studies find 47-55% of ChatGPT-generated academic citations are completely fabricated. AI-generated papers fool peer reviewers 32% of the time. Systematic hallucination threatens scholarly integrity.

events.title: Publishing Oligopoly Study
events.description: Research confirms Big Five publishers control 50%+ of academic publishing. Authors paid $1.06B in fees 2015-2018. Market concentration increased from 20% (1973) to 50% (2013).

events.title: Paper Mills Epidemic
events.description: Researchers estimate 400,000+ papers from 2000-2022 show paper mill hallmarks. At Wiley, ethics cases escalate from 175 in 2019 to 4,000 in 2023. Systematic fraud overwhelming peer review.

events.title: GPT-4 Released
events.description: OpenAI releases GPT-4 in March with dramatic improvements—90th percentile on bar exam (vs 10th for GPT-3.5), passes medical licensing exams, exceeds student average on 7 of 9 biomedical grad exams. Reduces citation hallucinations from 36% to 5.4%. Detects p-hacking in research protocols (88.6% accuracy).

protocolEffects.Inference: Advanced reasoning capabilities approached expert-level performance—GPT-4 could analyze research protocols, suggest experimental designs, and identify methodological flaws, augmenting researcher analytical capabilities.
protocolEffects.Quality: AI-based quality detection emerged—model could identify p-hacking and methodological issues with high accuracy, suggesting AI role in automated research integrity checking.

events.title: AI-Assisted Research Tools
events.description: Large language models and AI tools (ChatGPT, GPT-4, Claude, Copilot) begin transforming research workflows. Researchers use AI for literature review, hypothesis generation, code writing, data analysis, and paper drafting. Inference protocol goes digital-native.

protocolEffects.Inference: AI assistance transformed research workflows—language models helped with literature synthesis, hypothesis generation, code writing, and analysis, augmenting researcher capabilities and accelerating discovery pace.

events.title: ArXiv AI Moderation Crisis
events.description: Computer science category overwhelmed by AI-generated spam—hundreds of submissions monthly. Rejection rate jumps from 3% to 10%. Requires peer review before submission. Moderators can't keep up.

events.title: Frontiers Editorial Mass Resignations
events.description: Multiple mass editorial board resignations over peer review quality. Publications journal editors resign. AI-generated rat diagrams published. Editors describe profit-maximizing over quality.

events.title: NIH SBIR Fraud Investigation
events.description: GAO finds $34.7M in fraud settlements, 8% of small business awardees have fraud indicators, $445M in potentially duplicative work. System oversight failing.

events.title: Record Retraction Crisis
events.description: Over 10,000 papers retracted in 2023—new record. Hindawi retracts 8,000+ papers from paper mills. Retraction rate triples over past decade to 0.2%+. System overwhelmed.

events.title: Astera Institute Abandons Traditional Journals
events.description: Astera Institute and Arcadia Science discontinue support for traditional journal publications, declaring the century-old system 'fundamentally broken' and advocating for public peer review, preprints, and FAIR-compliant digital outputs.

protocolEffects.Quality: Public peer review on preprints replaces anonymous closed review—evaluation becomes transparent, continuous process rather than binary accept/reject gate.
protocolEffects.Engagement: Direct publication to open repositories bypasses journal paywalls and delays—research immediately accessible to anyone, not locked behind subscriptions.
protocolEffects.Preservation: FAIR-compliant digital outputs with persistent identifiers replace PDFs—machine-readable data and code preserved alongside narrative, enabling reuse.
protocolEffects.Coordination: Institutional commitment signals shift from journal prestige to research substance—researchers credited for outputs and contributions, not publication venue.
